Question_1.Context: Friction stir welding is a technique used to join materials by generating heat through friction and plastic deformation.
Question_1.Question: What is the most significant source of heat in Friction stir welding (FSW)?
Question_1.Source: Heat in FSW is generated by friction and plastic flow. Friction between tool and workpiece generates the most fraction of required heat.

Question_2.Context: In Friction stir welding, different regions with varying properties are formed due to heat distribution and plastic deformation.
Question_2.Question: What causes the formation of highly different regions in workpieces during FSW?
Question_2.B: Different plastic deformations and heat distributions
Question_2.C: The use of a single material
Question_2.Source: Due to asymmetrical heat distribution in FSW, different regions are formed in workpieces. These regions are highly different from each other because of different plastic deformations, heat distributions, residual stresses, and microstructures.

Question_3.Context: The position of materials being joined in FSW can affect the heat distribution and mechanical properties of the joint.
Question_3.Question: How does the position of dissimilar alloys in FSW affect the process?
Question_3.A: It has no significant effect on the process
Question_3.B: It changes the color of the weld
Question_3.C: It affects the maximum temperature and heat distribution
Question_3.D: It reduces the time needed for welding
Question_3.Source: The position of dissimilar alloys can highly affect the maximum temperature and heat distribution in FSW process.

Question_4.Context: Tool offsetting is a method used in FSW to control heat distribution and improve weld quality.
Question_4.Question: What is the purpose of offsetting the tool from the weld line in FSW?
Question_4.B: To avoid asymmetry of heat distribution at joints
Question_4.C: To reduce the amount of material used
Question_4.D: To create a decorative pattern on the weld
Question_4.Source: To avoid this disadvantage, one must offset tool from the weld line.

Question_5.Context: Pin offsetting is another technique used in FSW to influence the welding process.
Question_5.Question: What is the effect of offsetting the pin from the shoulder in FSW?
Question_5.A: Decreases the area of welded cross section
Question_5.B: Makes the process more environmentally friendly
Question_5.C: Leads to a decrease in the maximum temperature
Question_5.D: Increases the area of welded cross section
Question_5.Source: Offsetting the pin causes increment in plastic material flow in a constant pin volume, which leads to increase the area of welded cross section.

Question_6.Context: The mechanical properties of a weld joint can be influenced by the tool offset distance in FSW.
Question_6.Question: What has been observed regarding the effect of tool offset distance on mechanical properties in FSW?
Question_6.A: Offset distance has no impact on mechanical properties
Question_6.B: Offset distance can affect the mechanical properties and microstructures
Question_6.C: Offset distance only affects the color of the weld
Question_6.D: Offset distance decreases the welding time
Question_6.Source: The results show that offset distance can affect the mechanical properties and microstructures intensely.

Question_7.Context: In FSW, the ultimate tensile strength (UTS) of a joint can be optimized by adjusting the tool offset.
Question_7.Question: How does tool offset affect the ultimate tensile strength (UTS) in FSW?
Question_7.B: Offsetting has no effect on the UTS
Question_7.D: Offsetting increases the UTS only at high temperatures
Question_7.Source: Naghibi et al. (Naghibi et al., 2016) investigated the influence of tool offset on the UTS of AA5052 and AISI 304 weld joint and optimized UTS by genetic algorithm.

Question_8.Context: The position of materials in FSW, such as which side is advancing or retreating, can influence the joint's characteristics.
Question_8.Question: What is the effect of placing a harder alloy at the advancing side in FSW?
Question_8.C: Results in less maximum temperature increment
Question_8.D: Results in more maximum temperature increment
Question_8.Source: In all pin and tool offsettings, placing the harder alloy (AA6061) at advancing side results in more maximum temperature increment compared to the case which the harder alloy is at the retreating side.

Question_9.Context: The Response Surface Methodology (RSM) is a statistical method used to optimize processes by evaluating the effects of several variables.
Question_9.Question: What auxiliary method was used to investigate the effects of variables on the maximum temperature in FSW?
Question_9.Source: In this manner, Response Surface Methodology (RSM) as an auxiliary method has been used.

Question_10.Context: The Johnson-Cook model is a constitutive model used to describe the plasticity of materials under various conditions of strain, strain rate, and temperature.
Question_10.Question: Which constitutive model is used to simulate plastic flow in FSW?
Question_10.Source: To model the plastic flow, Johnson-Cook’s relation has been used.
